content:
We would have a much greater series of options to visually customize our whiteboards because currently we cannot easily make the text bigger or smaller (and in different formats) as per our needs.

Same with the images, but less, since you can scale the card that shows an image.
author: jagar

content:
Hi, wanted to share an opinion and ask about the "visuality options" of Hepta.

We currently have:
- Actual text inside cards (with integrated interoperability, backlinks…)
- Cards (which are visual containers of the interoperable text, with some meta-info)
- Arrows (mere visual artifacts, they have no connection with the interop. text)

I wanted to share a tool called Mural (https://mural.co/), **focusing on what it offers as visual aspects**. Maybe the dev team already knows about it, or maybe not.


What would be nice to have in Hepta is *more options for visual variety*.

Examples:
- Possibility to add **Pure Images**
- Possibility to give **Different Skins** to the card
- Possibility for more **Text Formatting**

Just thinking about it, a different "Skin" for a card could be: pure image. So, if the dev teams for some reason don't think it's the best to add pure images, we could have a Card but *skinned* as pure image. You click on it and it opens the fully detailed card as it happens now. One can decide to only have image(s) in it (and choose which one is to be the cover) and let it view as pure image on the board, or choose to see it as normal card. A card could be added multiple times on a WB, but with different skins.

Another Skin could be: *Sticky Note*, very commonly used by many people. Still a full card when you click on it, but visually a sticky note on the WB.

Another useful visual possibility would be to be able to add *plain text on the whiteboard*, not inside a card.

We could also have a **Pure Text** Skin for a card (or maybe not, that's the devs' decision) and have the possibility to format it, examples: greater font size, different text color, whatever.

With just these 2 additions (**Pure Images**, and **Pure Text**), we would have a much greater series of options to visually customize our whiteboards, which can be really important for easiness of managing them, easiness of recalling information, and just more visual appeal of the WBs.

author: my216

content:
Also <@701362327462739998> , I'm not trying to convince you that database is always better than file system, nor am I trying to convince you that Heptabase is better than other apps on all aspects (e.g., Kosmik), and I believe as a user, you should try all the options in the market and find one that fits best to your purpose.

Different apps have different purposes, and our goal is not only to create the best tool for comprehending knowledge but also eventually augment human collective intelligence by helping our users work together on top of a contextualized knowledge web, which makes everything mentioned above (multiplayer/syncing/performance/permission model/...) important to us, and lead to our choice of using the database instead of the file system.
author: Alan Chan

content: Of course it would be possible to provide a solution to enable reliable sync locally. It doesn't have to be in the cloud. But probably not something for you at the moment, if ever.
author: my216

content: Yeah, I know,  you would have to be very careful in that scenario or even just with two devices.
author: my216

content:
> they still live on a file system which can be synced

It's not that simple. Imagine you're using Heptabase offline in five devices. Then you try to sync data across these five devices, there will be sync conflicts, and something like iCloud won't know how to resolve these conflicts (the best it can do is to choose the latest-edited one and then you'll lose data from other devices). Database implementation allows you to perform special sync algorithm to resolve conflicts.
author: Alan Chan

content:
Quite familiar with databases and I don't have a problem with that.
But they still live on a file system which can be synced. You have to be careful obviously, but a single user should be able to manage that to ensure only one computer is used at a time and that sync is completed before opening the app on another.
author: my216

content: Also, database is not "hidden." You can still see it if you open your developer tool. It's just that you can't see it through folders.
author: Alan Chan

content: In short, based on our research, if you eventually want your app to support realtime sync + multiplayer editing + offline editing in multiple devices (and auto resolve editing conflict) + good performance in larger scale + complex permission model (share certain data to certain people), database is definitely a better choice. I don't think any app that use file system to store data can do that.
author: Alan Chan

content:
I'm not sure how much you understand database, but here's a good reference that shows the difference between database and file system:
https://www.interviewbit.com/blog/file-system-vs-dbms/

> **Q1.** Is a database better than a file system?
> 
> **Ans.** Both database management systems and file systems have their own advantages and disadvantages as mentioned above. While a database management system offers reduced redundancy, reduced inconsistency, and improved query processing, it is much costlier than a file system. Also, it is much more complex. Hence, it depends on the requirements as to which would be a better choice to go ahead with. For a small-scale business, a file system would be the better option whereas, for a big-scale business, a database management system would be much better.

content:
Feature Request: **About Move to Whiteboard**
As is :
Ctrl + M = Remove from current whiteboard and move to another whiteboard
Pain point :
When I'm browsing Whiteboard-A , I want to duplicate and sync a card to Whiteboard-B, without breaking the current card layout and connection in Whiteboard-A. 
But Ctrl + M will remove that card from Whiteboard-A, so I can't use that function. 
Instead, I have to take many additional steps to complete the action stated above.
Whiteboard-A = a structured domain knowledge.
Whiteboard-B = a new project which requires multiple cards from different whiteboard.
-
Suggestion:
Add another function called "Duplicate to" (Ctrl + Shift + M)
Ctrl + M = Remove from current whiteboard and move to another whiteboard
**Ctrl + Shift + M** = Keep card in current whiteboard, duplicate and sync the card to another whiteboard

content:
Hi Heptabase team, 

你好，我是一位在科技業從事十年左右的工程師，平時熱愛嘗試新鮮事物
很感謝你們製作了這麼棒的工具，
付費使用幾天後有一些我覺得可以改善的地方 
說是改善或許有點驕縱了，

有可能是我使用方式不對，
抑或是開發團隊在這項功能的定義或思維有獨到的見解  (如果觀點很好我也可以改變使用習慣)

如果有任何認知或使用方法有誤請幫忙指證，謝謝

- **沒有 unlinked reference 功能**
1. 輸入的流暢度：例如一段話裡面可能有數個重要的詞，還是得製成卡片或連結到卡片，不然以後無法找到，那麼完成這段輸入的效率就會打折扣

2. 隨手打在 Journal 筆記或靈感，如果沒有把其中一個 term 製成卡片 or tag， 若沒有unlinked reference, 時日一長就大海撈針，這個可能可以透過每日勤加整理的使用習慣，但還是希望有此功能

3. 以上兩點雖然可以透過基本的搜尋功能找到卡片，不過右邊的預覽圖只會顯示卡片的整體，並沒法標示出出現在卡片的哪個地方

4. 大概想的到會增加複雜度，例如顯示頁面時讀取時間會比較久一點

5. 可能會讓頁面看起來雜亂，不過 Logseq 的處理方式我覺得還不錯，預設是收起來的 (摺疊)

author: Alan Chan

content:
Hi <@779015270311395370> ,

sorry if it's not appropriate to tag you, but I wrote something earlier and wanted to ask for a confirmation.

Is this card https://discord.com/channels/812292969183969301/856016076311101470/1007701396050694154
"Hot key to navigate cards / move around"

going to be implemented as described here: https://discord.com/channels/812292969183969301/856016076311101470/1007630678751465482

If not, could you please describe how it is going to work?



Also, on another note, do you have plans to implement ways to allow users to use a "more diverse range of text formatting"?
Examples
Sometimes, you'd like to use just a brief title for a card perhaps linked with some other cards around it or not.
But this card with the brief title, you somehow want it to stand out a bit more with respect of other cards nearby.
In that case it'd would be useful to for instance, having the possibility for the text size to 'follow' the card size. Just like images, the text could increase itsefl when we increase the card.
Not to be applied for every text of course. Just some.

Or another example: having the possibility to change the font of some text. Or even color?

The main idea is that: we are plotting cards over a 2d physical space (whiteboard), so that our visual processing mental area could be "better stimulated".
Instead of having a boring 'text wall' (even if it can be outlined as in Obsidian or Logseq), the whiteboard should give better mind stimulation.

So having another dimension for changes, like being able to differentiate the text inside cards should increase the stimulation.

Because now, when we write a lot of cards inside a whiteboard, we can only play with the card color and card size, but many cards will still look quite similar if we don't need to change color that much. For instance because the info collected are similar in category.
Having bigger texts will also allow for faster reading on scaled out wb.

author: jagar

content:
I know this flow gives way more speed because there is a tiny Mac app called "BetterSnapTool" that I immediately install in every new Mac installation because it's just so useful.

It allows to move (and also resize) any window of the applications in the way described.

No need to position the cursor over the top bar of the app and press down the left button to move a window. Just have the cursor over any part of the window, press the keyboard buttons, and then just move the cursor.
It is just so quick.

That app also allows to resize any windown, without having to go with the cursor directly at the border of the window, just place the cursor over any part of a window, press down the keyboard buttons, and move the cursor (not need to press down the left button of the mouse).

Hope you would consider this quality-of-life improvement for the next releases.

Thank you very much.
author: jagar

content:
Regarding order and tidiness of the cards inside a whiteboard:

I think it is safe to say that the main focus of using Hepta is about inputting/collecting content, and/or creating new content based on the thinking/analysis done on the collected content.

A subsidiary/ancillary set of operations to support the main focus is about placing and moving the cards inside a whiteboard to allow an overall better understanding of the content.

A quality-of-life aspect then could be the *speed*, and in parallel the *friction*, that is intrinsically exhibited by the current flow.
The less friction, the greater speed.

On the placement and moving of cards, I know it is already planned to improve the alignment and snapping of cards, on the roadm ap: "Whiteboard: Alignment guidelines & better snapping".


What I'd like to ask is about a significant decrease of friction in moving the cards.
The current way of moving cards is:
- The cursor needs to be positioned at the top bar of a card when it's unfolded (or inside the folded card area)
- press down the left button of the mouse (or trackpad)
- move the mouse (or finger over the trackpad), *while* the finger pressed down
- release the finger when the card is positioned where it's needed


The proposal is about the following:
- having a hotkey to be pressed on the keyboard, example: CMD+ALT (just these two)
- a this point, the user can position the cursor over *any point of the entire area* of a card, not just the top bar when it's unfolded
- press down the hotkeys, in this example the two keyboard buttons CMD+ALT
- no need to press down the left button of the mouse (or trackpad)
- just freely move the mouse (or finger over the trackpad)
- when card is positioned where it's needed, just release the two keyboard buttons


The increment of speed is given by:
- freedom to position the cursor over the entire area of the card
- not having to continuously press down the left button of the mouse
author: jagar

content:
Hello, 

At this link of Hepta Use Cases: https://heptaplatforms.notion.site/Use-Case-How-people-are-using-Heptabase-70c85a0c686945218427618549087629
Section: "Keep track on what I know and what I don't know"

There is screenshot of a whiteboard. It shows a way of using cards a BIG TITLES on top of other cards, which is nice.

One thing that is marginally related to these kind of cards, meaning it could be applied to other kind of cards/blocks:

- Possibility to Align the Text in a block:
     - **Align to Right**
     - **Align to Left**
     - **Center**
    - Possibly Justify as well maybe, but not sure if it could be needed


Having the possibility to center the text will give a more pleasant presentation of the TITLE Cards at the top.

The current only way of placing the Text at the center is to manually add several blank spaces before the text. We know it's not an optimal way though (it is tiresome and if the card width changes, the text is not centered anymore for example).

Just to avoid misunderstandings, I'm talking about the horizontal centering of a text.
I may imagine that centering the text vertically as well may not be possible perhaps, because of how the blocks are structured inside a card.

content: Hook
author: Alan Chan

content:
Is it possible to have Heptabase work with Hook? For the record, hook is an amazing application that provides system wide linking/backlinking features. 

Basically, if I'm navigating a page in safari or even a file in finder, I can copy the link to that resource. I can then create an apple note or in any other note taking app and link this note to the link created by hook (for a webpage it'll be the url, for a file it'll be a file://, for other apps, like omnifocus, it will be omnifocus://xxxx). Then whenever I open this same url or focus on the file in finder, I can invoke hook and it'll allow me to jump to the note I've created. Similarly, if I open the note, I can invoke hook and it'll jump to the url or file in finder (or any other resource).

It's possible to have hook integrate with Hepta provided hepta is able to provide references to its notes.

It's also possible to integrate more by providing an API to directly create a note from hook, the use case being: I have my focus on a given pdf file in my finder, I invoke hook and I would be able to trigger, "create new note in hepta", it will create a new note, paste a link to this pdf in the note and link the two at hook level.

It may seem a bit abstract, it was not clear to me how it was working at the beginning, but after using it for a while it proves to be super useful. As an example of nice integration, craft and obsidian are integrated with the tool. It would be nice to have a similar integration with Hepta.

To have it work with Hepta, there are a few requirements that are explained on Hook page: 

- Homepage: https://hookproductivity.com

- How to make the app linkable: https://hookproductivity.com/help/integration/information-for-developers-api-requirements/

author: Sharknader

content:
<#856016076311101470> 
On a Whiteboard, after opening the Card Library on the right sidebar to import them.

Sometimes you are not 100% sure which card needs to be imported because there could be a few similar cards that perhaps have small differences just in the content, or the tags, or in which whiteboards they are in.

Or perhaps, before importing them, you would just like to see their info for any reason.

Feature Request: Be able to see the Card Info **before** importing them, right from the Card Library list of cards.
Something like: double click on a card in the Card Library, and its details are opened at the center of the screen, similarly to how they get opened when you click on a card in the Card Library opened *from the left sidebar*.

It would kinda also be more of a "consistent" behavior because we have the same feature "Card Library" openable from the Right sidebar, and also openable from the left sidebar. 
But the one openable from the right sidebar does not give the possibility to show the card info when clicking (or double clicking, or whatever other trigger you think of) on it.

Even though the two Card Library are essentially the same as they both list all the cards, and they both have the same ways to filter them at the top (All Cards, Uncategorized, Filter Tags, Filter Whiteboards, Custom Filters). So it would be more consistent to be able to see the card info from the Card Library opened from the Right sidebar.
author: jagar

content:
Feature Request for text editor (minor priority)
Scenario: 
When I want to perform an action to internal and external links.
As-is:
-  Use mouse to select precisely the entire text, (2) Left-click/Ctrl+K on "link" menu, (3) Perform remove/copy action.
- If I want to remove a lengthy hyperlink text, I have to select precisely the entire text area. Sometimes with multiple failed attempt.
Wish:
- When we right-click on the text (no matter where), show the link menu
---
Benefit:
Easier operation to remove/copy a lengthy hyperlink text.

Types of search logic

Right hand search strings?
> refers to the ability to search on the initial string of characters in a word. In a sample words, right-hand truncation ignoring the end of a word. The truncation ‘IM’ will for example, retrieve documents containing important impossible, impolite, import etc.

Or maybe Boolean search strings?
author: Sams_Here

content:
Hi, regarding searching of a card, especially after typing @ inside another card

Let's make an example: searching for the card titled:
- "Who are your competitors?"

Currently, to retreive the card we want, if we start from the first word (which is the most common case I believe), we *have to* write the complete word before typing the next one. 
So, currently, we need to type: "who are"

Instead, the search could be faster if we can just type some of the letters that are in the title, example: "wh com"


Another example: we have cards for a book of 20 chapters. There are 20 cards one for each chapter. They all start with the word "Chapter" followed by the number: "Chapter 1", "Chapter 2", ... and so on.

Currentl, if we want to link a chapter cards into another card, we have to write the full word "chapter" before specifying the number.
It would be easier and much quicker if we can just type "cha 1" or "ch 1" (instead of "chapter 1") and the card titled "Chapter 1" appears in the search result.


I know there is a name for this kind of search, but I don't remember it.
Hope the examples are clear enough.

Is there a chance it will be added to the roadmap later on?

Thanks

author: Skyline

content:
<@779015270311395370> I played around in the app and apparently there are two different behaviors for "Entering" a whiteboard.

Firstly, when you keep the pointer over a whiteboard, a small popup appears at the top of the whiteboard card with the text:
"Double Click to enter
Drag to move"

At the moment there are 3 different ways to 'enter' a whiteboad:
1. Double click on it
2. Clicking the small icon at the top right of the whiteboard (a small image of a rectangle with an arrow pointing up)
3. Right-click on the whiteboard, a popup with some options will appear, select "Enter" from it

From a user experience point of view, it is perhaps expected that all the 3 option will have the same exact effect (because it is always just used the word "Enter"), but, at least in this last version 0.179.0, that's not the case.

What happens regarding the Whiteboard shown in the Working Tabs list is the following:
- By using option 1 and 2 the current Whiteboard that is already shown in the working tab is *replaced* by the one we are entering;
- But, by using option 3 (with the right-click), the currently open whiteboard remains in the Working Tabs list, and the one we are opening is immediately added below the previous one.


Is this a bug or an expected behavior?

Thanks

author: 瓦基

content:
Request:
A better hotkey mechanism for "Alt + ← / →"
-
First, I love this hotkey:
Alt + ← / → (Win) to go to previous/next place.
With only one exception:
-
When I open a card in a Card Library or search by Ctrl+O or Ctrl+P, the card was "zoom-to-center" view mode as attached image.
Under this scenario, my intention is to view card by card (clicking internal link) to find the most appropriate one to use. 
But there is no "backward/forward" hotkey during the "zoom-to-center" view mode. (or there is?)
I find it's hard to keep the streamline of thoughts if I can't move fast during the browsing.
-
My suggestion:
Make Alt + ← / → (Win) to perform "backward/forward" in "zoom-to-center" view mode.
(Add a left/right arrow to top-left would be even better.)
-
Reason:
Since "zoom-to-center" view mode already BLOCKED most of the view,
there's no point to switch back and forth between Journal / Whiteboard / Map / Card Library / Tags during "zoom-to-center" view mode.
Under this scenario, Alt + ← / → (Win) would be a better replacement to perform "backward/forward" in "zoom-to-center" view mode.
It's intuitive enough since you know what you're focusing on your screen, and we don't need to remember another hotkey.

author: Alan Chan

content:
v0.172.1
Performance request:
-
(1) When typing in the card title section, there's an obvious delay-time about 0.5~1 second
I guess Heptabase judge every title input at first, then display text later.
This mechanism, maybe, was designed to sync same title name is different cards with the same title.
My suggestion:
When typing in the title, display at first, then judge every input later in the background.
The syncing of the card title is NOT a time-critical task, but the delay of the display really drags user experience.
-
(2) When there is an internal link card name existed inside a same note, the link name is NOT synced.
In this case, the internal link of 「個體稀缺」 sits inside the same card, the naming is not synced.
Request scenario:
I often finish a NEW content while typing in an old card.
Next, I create a NEW card with a keyword or sentence, then copy the entire NEW content to the NEW card.
I don't want to manually remove the internal link in the NEW card, I also think there's no need for doing so.
Later, when I change the card title, I'd like to see the internal link name was synced as well.
The above scenario was performed in all Whiteboard, Tab, Journal.

author: rubickwilde

content:
v0.170.0
A Drag-and-Drop Optimisation Request:
---
When I want to move single/multiple card(s) across a whiteboard, the experience is not smooth.
As shown, 
1) I selected 3 cards
2) move them for a distance
3) I "right-click" on the whiteboard to move further ( because I want to move cards far away, keeping their original layout )
4) Then, the SELECTION of cards was removed.
5) I have to select them again, and repeat step 1) ~ 3)
---
- The steps above requires multiple "precise" selections
- The larger the whiteboard, more painful the experience
- The more complex of the layout of the cards, more painful the experience
- The pain increases with the increasing size of whiteboard 
p.s. I'm not a fan of multi-layer whiteboard (I only use multi-layer whiteboard under few conditions), I prefer to browse notes in a big glance, then Drag-and-Drop and create connection
---
Request: Keep the "selection" of card(s) no matter how user move the whiteboard.

content:
**Automatic Date Logs**

**FEATURE DESCRIPTION: **For every card (and white boards), the system should automatically track the creation date and most recent update date. It could be displayed in Card Info by default.

**USE CASE:**  Automatic dates let you go back and see when you created something. For example, if you are taking notes, it means the date is there and you do not have to manually enter the date. Notion does all this by default. You could also potentially use this info to sort cards by date.

author: summerdreams

content:
I've been enjoying breaking down the findings and arguments of research papers in Heptabase into Cards. The bottleneck for me now is taking screenshots (of PDF files) and creating Cards, and I wonder if we can make it easier while we are thinking Better Exploring. My current workflow is roughly like this:
1. Open Heptabase and a PDF reader side by side
2. Take screenshots of a part of paper I want
3. Click on a whiteboard to create a card
4. Paste the screenshot into the card
5. Write notes on the Card and make connections
6. Repeat 2-5 many many times depending on the complexity of the paper

Can we make this flow more smooth? For example, can we combine Steps 1 2 3 4 by opening a PDF file in Heptabase and I can select part of PDF file and drag it to the whiteboard to create a card (and no more manual screenshots)?
author: cyb3rm4x

content: Can we consider opening a card in a Whiteboard directly in Universal Search Cmd+O? Surely it's useful to find a Card and see the card in the pop-up mode with Enter if all I need is the content of the Card. However, sometimes I need to access the spatial context of a Card on a Whiteboard in addition to the content, and would be more convenient if I can directly in Universal Search results to open the Card in the Universal Search result on the corresponding Whiteboard. My workaround now is to hit Enter, scroll down the Card to Card Info, and click the Whiteboards backlink. It would be great to just skip the Card in the pop-up mode.

author: char_lie

content:
I'll jump in to say* that a 'low-feature' free version could also be referred to as 'crippleware' (at least it was called that back in the day when 'freeware' was really free). 
> *While crippleware allows consumers to see the software before they buy, they are unable to test its complete functionality because of the disabled functions* - `https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crippleware`
My personal opinion is a limited-functioning Heptabase would do more harm than good for prospective new users. Would you want to test drive a car with limited features? You might, but you would walk away with questions and a frustration of not knowing how the vehicle can ultimately perform.

*and I've been wrong before!

This is an incredibly insightful, thoughtful article! https://medium.com/heptabase/my-vision-a-forgotten-history-67ee77e969da

When I pasted the link into Hepta, I got to thinking about whether link editing in Hepta might be a bit easier. For instance, I love how Bear has a link icon next to an external link. This makes it easy to both click and edit. Clicking the red text pops open a browser tab at the URL.

author: Rodrigo Faerman

content:
I'd like to be able to export selected cards in the order I want as a rich text document (one document - not multiple separate files). I would imagine it might work similarly to how it works now in the card library, but I should be able to sort the cards manually as I need, which I believe is not possible now. That's probably easy to implement and could be very useful. 
My usage scenario is writing fiction in Heptabase (or at least I want it to be because now Heptabase lacks necessary functionality). A card would be a scene or a beat. I could tag the cards with something like #manuscript so that I would be able to filter those later for export. Even better would be to have them sorted automatically, from left to right first, then from the top down. Let's assume I have cards organized in columns as chapters and rows as scenes.
The best way would be to be able to group cards into larger units and order the groups as I wish 😁.  

Another thing I'm missing for this scenario is the fiction paragraph style. Now the paragraph style is like in non-fiction books (an empty line between paragraphs with no indent). 

But maybe it's asking for too much 😉.

author: 올댓

content: thanks for your sharing. i think it will help more users to know more about flexible freedom of function issue and rethink how they use the tools.
author: easontseng

content:
I understand overlaps of functions and uses can make it trickier for some users on 'how to use' or 'how to organize' - but said overlap is inevitable in flexible apps, and by the variety of personas and usecases interested in hepta (and each one with their preferences) i think the flexibility should stay

for example do we put everything in 1 board, less boards, or many boards? nested boards or not? tags or boards?
when apps kill any and all redudancies they make it easier to get into but reduce extremely who will want to use then. Logseq have 1 way of doing things and i struggled with it. Obsidian i struggled with. Mem kills any and all choice from the user and despite some useful features i couldnt make it work for me... the list goes on

Freedom and overlaps have a cost- like people unsure how to layout things... thats the reason why notions reddit is full of tips and templates sharing, and tons of videos on youtube...

but the thing is that freedom is what made notion such a popular hit in the first place. Evernote is similar and been around for decades and didnt grow like notion did ever. Google keep been around for longer but theres no passion nor growth for it... obsidian pales in comparison to notion but its the most popular zettel focused app out there amongst dozens (theres a lot of alternatives, i test all of then), also full of community sharing and its a MESS in terms of how complex things can get with plugins

Everyone wants the tool that catters best to then but everyone is different. The secret formula (and tricky part) is how to make such flexible freedom 'make your it your own' as simple to get and use as possible. Notion did it pretty well as far as its possible and id say hepta been doing it pretty damn well too
author: Vincer

content:
but id argue that 'habit' of some users and designers/teams is avoidable by design- like an app with both features that dont mix then like logseq does.
Theres no graph in hepta right now but there was and i think the feature will come back- the graph is a great way for users to clearly see the difference. The app and tutorials could mention and show examples of how to use things but even without doing it users would find out naturally ('oh i can filter by tags, not mentions' 'hm mentions show links in the graph and backlinks')

but definetly better comunicating that would be better.
Showing tags as pills on the card would do well...

I also think a requested feature would really help here- showing tags on cards, like appearing on hover or always being show
I think that alone would clear any confusions- the tags would be really tagging the cards with labels, while mentions would appear as non intrusive hyperlinks in text like were all used to, since its the same as hyperlinks on the web

Most users wouldnt even need to know or use inline tags- more like a surprise 'oh i can also link to a tag!'- and by then appearing different (like the pill they already see on cards) it would make sense
author: Vincer

content: i believe the confusion comes because of many apps and users where the misuse of each happens; like apps that only have tags or only have mentions have users using 1 single feature for both usecases
author: Vincer

content:
i understand the questions. Logseq for example gave up on the debate and uses tags=mentions (it really only changes the display and input, but in logseq theyre the same thing)

Thing is tags and mentions already have a difference in Hepta- we can filter all cards by tag, not by mention; Cards show every mention to then as backlinks, not every card that uses the same tag as then in backlinks

The very concept of both are different from the start- tags is typology, classification. From the time before computers to this day theyre meant to say 'this is type x, that type y' - groups that can overlap but the itens in each group arent necessarily related to each other

Mentions on the other hand come from zettelkasten (also before computers), and also from hyperlinks (early internet) with the same concept- indicating A is related to B directly, not as 'same type'

In a graph for example (like obsidians, and heptas early graph feature) it would make sense for cards of a company, a product and a project showing a connection between then (say its a product from said company and its related to a particular project)
-that would be mentions, direct links... between things that arent the same type (a company, a product, a project, different types)

But the same graph shouldnt link for example that product with another product just because theyre both products. Imagine in the example theres other companies and products on the user library, but they wouldnt be connected just because they share the same type

The type(tag) is still very useful when we want to filter for, search and compare things that arent directly related. I could list all companies only, all products only and so on
author: Vincer

author: Vincer

content:
這幾天看到好多inline tag的討論，我自己腦補一個中庸的方式：
系統支持輸入`#tag` 形同標記`[[#tag]]` （就像支持`＠`形同`[[]]`一樣），這張`[[#tag]]` 統一在`Tags`的白板內。
如果雙鏈時沒有這張`[[#tag]]`卡片，就在`Tags` 中新建一張`[[#tag]]`卡片。然後也提供一個現在的Tags Viewer功能。
至於其他關於inline tag 能不能寫內容，或是可不可以connection的問題，確實是設計上引導使用者建立習慣的方式，這個還是尊重開發者的設計理念。
畢竟現有的mention就可以表示tag的功能，只是部分使用者無法自行明確區隔開來mention、tag間的差異而已。
author: easontseng

author: Carl-bot

content:
**Sidebar shortcut hotkeys**
Ive mentioned 2 windows in the past, while that isnt in the foreseable future i tought of a possible time saver alternative- swapping screens (boards, cards) via hotkeys
A hotkey like ctrl+1, 2...9 or 0 making hepta imediatly jump to/select tabs on the sidebar, by their current order
So the first tab would be ctrl+1, second ctrl+2 etc

There could be a toggeable setting to show quickacess tabs numbers before their titles (adding a 1-9 or 1-10 number before the top 9-10 tabs)
toggeable would be best since the numbers would be great for those using the feature but probably just be noise for those who dont (in particular mobile with no keyboard attached)

*numbers showing wouldnt be crucial tough. Between no hotkey swaping and swaping without numbers showing i would take swaping every time, and keep some useful always checked boards/notes in a fixed order, memory would do the rest*
author: Vincer

content: **Color blocks:** changing the type color of blocks. Could be the same colors as the ones for cards backgrounds, only applied to the letters instead
author: Vincer

content:
**Adding tags directly on cards inline**
An idea for tagging with inline tags in mind- the easiest way i guess: any tags typed inside a card (say #tag) would already be applied to the card as whole.
Filterting for tags showing only the block that matches the inline tag as its card thumbnail would be best- but even without that, showing the entire card would already be good
My idea:
Inline tags v1: just applies tags to the whole card when typed. Recognizes tags (#tag) and shows autofill tag dropdown when typing then
Inline tags v2(future): searching for/filterting tags shows their blocks, not the whole cards that used tags inline

author: Vincer

content:
**Vertical Scrolling Journal Timeline**
I love the journal and timeline view for the card library- but i miss the scrolling of timeline in the journal.
Ive been taking journal notes in logseq, that work pretty much like the timeline view in hepta, and the difference for me is light and day- it makes much easier to look back on the past journal entries or even see at a glance what was the last(previous) journal entry

Dont get me wrong, im not talking about bringing the timeline back where the journal is- having then separate is the most important part, a no-whiteboard zone to just type right away

In the current view (locked to 1 journal) if my last journal entry was more then 6 days ago i wouldnt see a cue to it for example, only by clicking in the calendar.
Also looking for a specific thing written in a journal entry- without a clear idea witch day- means clicking on the calendar and then each day, then on the calendar again and so on...

My sugestions:
*A) bellow current day scrolling*
At the bottom of the journal page showing the previous journal (that was filled in), making journal also works as a timeline view (of the journal only) just by scrolling
*B) A previously button/toggle on the botton*
Once clicked it expands the previous entries for scrolling
*C) Timeline button (top-right)*
For consistency, using the same button and icon for the timeline view in the card library

content:
Hi all,

author: Alan Chan

content:
Currently I'm a math student, and I plan to transcribe my professors scripts and other theorems from books for example into hepta. Most of the math material, that I know often uses either alphabetical lists as in my example or roman numerals as in i, ii, iii, iv,...

This feature would really help me transcribe the content from my studies more accurately, so that when the professor mentions "17.3 (c)" I don't have to search for "17.3 3"

It's really just a small thing but I find customizing list styles a really nice and also rare feature :)

author: Sharknader

content:
Request related to tags: 
1. It would be really helpful to filter by a combination of tags in the "Import cards" view, library view and tag view, as opposed to one tag at a time. That would allow filtering for things like "#bug" and #"project_A", so you could see all the bugs related to a project across all the whiteboards and the timeline. 
2. Being able to visually filter cards on a whiteboard would be amazing, either via plain text search or tags, so that only the query results would be shown (and maybe other cards would be dimmed). 
3. If card names, tags and whiteboard links all functioned as basically tags, and could be filtered by references to these in any combination, that would allow for greater cross-whiteboard connections and remove the brain damage of trying to figure out whether you want to create a card, a tag or refer to another whiteboard when trying to connect ideas.
PS: also strongly support inline tagging and block links. That would be amazing if/when implemented.

content:
hello.!
I'm the person who canceled my subscription and came back... (heptabase's white board is so good)


(I'm not good at English and I don't understand the conversation culture, so I'd like to use a translator. Even if my text is rude, I want to let you know that my heart is very respectful... Please forgive me!)

I would like to suggest some new concepts+features.
A white board is not "just" a white board.
1. This white board should be able to link to the text inside the card.
2. Overlapping white boards and cards on the white board must be connected with arrows.
3. The white board should be able to preview inside the card, and it should be possible to preview in other white boards as well.

author: josh stark

author: Alan Chan

content:
Would it be possible to have a feature similar to the sync blocks in other apps in the market? The flow I am trying to achieve is,

I am trying to use the timeline view as a daily planner. I have projects in whiteboards with cards holding the notes/data/information and also tasks to be done in the project. I copy paste the tasks into my daily planner so I don't have to navigate to different boards and see my pending tasks. I will not be able to sync the status of those tasks if I just copy and paste.

With something like sync blocks, I can imaging embedding card content or blocks into a card from the timeline and they all share the status of the content. This way planning is just linking appropriate blocks of text. Does this make sense? You can ignore this, if there is a feature down the road for task management as that would be a more appropriate solution.

content:
Hello hepta team, 
It would be really helpful to be able to jump to the card **within the whiteboard** where it's located from the global search window. Using ctrl/cmd+enter or something. I know it could be challenging UI-wise because the card could exist in multiple whiteboards. Maybe a dropdown with available whiteboards would appear. I think this feature would dramatically improve the navigation experience. While searching for a card, in many cases we want to also see the *context* of it - therefore - it's whiteboard, and right now we need to first open the card, then go to 'Card info' section and then click the whiteboard.

**FR: Going directly to card from map/board views**
as in some re-implementation of something hepta used to allow- on map view being able to click on one of the card titles inside and go directly to it (go to board focused on the clicked card)
Its was a useful timesaver before, but now that we finally have nestable boards it would be even more useful, as im already stretching some nested boards to have a list of whats inside readily visible, being able to go from said view (inside a board looking at a nested board) straight to one of the small titles in the nested board would be awesome... heck, it could feel almost like menus

On mobile/touch: touch and hold for 3 seconds
On desktop: click and hold a particular card, also a could have a shortcut (ex: ctrl+click, shift+click etc)

A short term workaround: Add dates within your timeline notes (e.g., 05/17/22 or the like). You can then search dates via the card library. (this is what I have been doing)

author: cyb3rm4x

content:
I think its search function is on a block base, not a page or a card base. I can't search 2 words seperated in 2 lines same time. It's a bit problematic if you have a big amount of notes and cards in one library. 

And also search function is too strict. If one line has '1 2' than I can't search '2 1' in search field to see that card. You guys don't provide 'unlinked cards' function, than fuzzy search more than 2 words is critical to find a card what I want.

author: Carl-bot

content: Please don't change the behavior such that typing '/' while writing automatically opens the block selection list. I’m fine with this being the default behavior at the beginning of a block, however. This is one of my biggest issues with apps like Notion, Logseq, and Anytype. I use the slash character quite frequently in my own writing, and seeing an irrelevant menu pop up constantly is pretty distracting. The current solution works well enough, but it’s not perfect. It would be better if we kept the current ‘ctrl + /’ activation , along with allowing the user to save their position in the block they were editing. Under the current paradigm, the entire block is selected. While the user may easily navigate to the end of the block by pressing Enter, not every scenario is best served by imposing this one-size-fits-all solution. Instead, by combining the behavior employed by Logseq (where the cursor remains in place) and the present shortcut, a better interaction model can be achieved.

content: Can we give some love to the slash command? Currently users can only trigger slash command at the beginning of the paragraph. author: lisatomic

content:
I would love to have "layers" that I can toggle on and off within a whiteboard.

As boards get more complex, it can be hard to see certain relationships among all cards. It would be useful if I could selectively view certain cards and not others, but still retain all their relational information without losing it. 

Example use-case: I have a board that describes "priorities and goals" for the year, articulating the logical relationships between them, and including the argument for why they'd matter. 

I'd like to fill out the board with cards representing every project that relates to those goals, drawing connections between them.

But all of that information all at once is quite overwhelming. What I'd like to do is to be able to see the "core" information on the board, and then turn on/off a layer that also shows projects.

author: Quick

content:
Hi, I just joined Hepta and have to say that I'm loving the product.

I'm a 3d artist and as part of my workflow I use a "Mood Board" where I capture tweets from other 3d artists. It would be nice to be able to paste a twitter link into a Card, and have the tweet be auto embedded. Right now I'm having to screenshot the tweet and add a link to the tweet manually. It works ok, but it does break away the process a little. This is something I really liked when using Roam, that I could just copy/paste a tweet and it would auto embed.

As an additional thought, some tweets come with video content, and it would be so helpful if the playable content was also playable on Hepta.

I searched the server and didn't see this being suggested so posting here. I saw video embedding is already being considered which is awesome! Thanks for all the work, this is a great product!

author: 元月

content: I’m not against this suggestion. Some way to quickly see and interact with tags would be wonderful. But the bigger problem is what role tags play in general and in the context of Hepta. Tags are scaffolds that are really only useful when you need and can apply sorting, filtering etc to them, and when the number of objects are bigger. It’s not very useful, counterproductive even, on its own. Of course when you do have a lot of objects, you run into other problems that only AI can solve, but that’s a different topic. Right now, tags are in a somewhat oblivion state not just because it’s more hidden in interface, but because Hepta leans heavily on functions within the scope of a whiteboard.

content: FR: Import Directory (+subdirectories optional). On import, Hepta will automatically tag all imported cards with a unique ID. If user selects "include subdirectories", then those imported notes will be tagged with the generated uid+sub-directory_name. After import, the user can then view all the cards using the auto-tags that were generated and either rename tags or re-tag using the tag management functionality already available. Use-case: someone who wants to import an existing knowledge-base quickly and effortlessly.

author: Sams_Here

content:
Feature Request:

It would be nice if Heptabase would preserve the spacing in any given card.

Background:

While working in a whiteboard, oftentimes I’ll find myself adding spaces (empty blocks) between text blocks to indicate to myself that I either want to input content there later or to just help me think. Most of the time, though, it just serves a a reminder that I’m going to write something in that area. I certainly could add some placeholder text to be deleted later, but that’s just inconvenient for me. The same applies for when I’m working full screen on a note, writing prose. When I return to a note, it’s mildly bothersome (to say the least) to find that any spaces I had left between blocks, at the beginning or end of the document, have now disappeared.
author: prixsen

content:
Feature request:

Heptabase opens to where the user last left off in their work, after the app was closed. Whether you were looking at a card in full screen or working in a whiteboard, that's exactly what you'll see when you return.

This is a nice quality of life feature to have that other users might be accustomed to, if they use other apps.

author: Praise Chu

content:
Is there any kind of hacking/plugin mechanism yet? I would like to try out a few little experiments, here is my use-case.

The feature in Hepta: "After a board is updated (cards added or moved), I want to receive an event with the board info and card meta-data (tags & positions) and a way to update the card positions."

Then some experiments I would like to try out:
- **Snap to grid ** - auto-arrange cards by fitting them on a common grid (round to next multiple for x/y coorditanes and width/height)
- **Lists** - Cards are auto-arranged in a list under each other, potentially a 'container' card acts as the boundary for the list, you can drag other cards inside this boundary and they will be added to the list.
    - **Accordion** - Special mode of the list where the cards are collapsed and you can open one at a time (for this the event handler would need to know the 'previous state' as well, so that I can determine which card was opened and close all others)
    - **Queue** - A special list where the first and last element are expanded and the other ones are collapsed (could be nice for organizing/prioritizing your work/todo list)

"@todo-tracker"and within the todo-tracker card, i copy and paste the to-do list and append the backlink to where it originated from. Each time i cross a list, i'll click on the backlink and strike it out from that page as well. Its tedious, but at least i have some control of the list. Else, the list will just be another to-do list that gets buried in piles of notes.

content: Can we consider adding a search filter for colors in "Card Library"? I use color to highlight cards on the whiteboard that I'd like to keep going back to (e.g.,  questions I'm pondering and still not resolved yet). I'd like to have a way of list all cards of a particular color in "Card Library" for me to see all of them across whiteboards, and select the one I'd like to think a bit more and go back to. Currently I need to visit each whiteboard and find these cards of particular color and decide the priority. I think about other workarounds, but they will defeat the purpose of color-coding cards on whiteboard: I can add special keywords, I can assign tags to cards, but none of them will stand up on the whiteboard in a glance. content:
As much as I would think it fits Hepta vision to have an app (just like Timeline, Tags, Map, and Cards Library) that manage tasks stored in various cards, this is clearly not on Hepta's short-term roadmap [1]. My workaround is to just don't even try to do any task management in Hepta at all (this adds friction as most note-taking tools have task and knowledge management close and supports various date-related operations like reminders, date pickers etc), but I'm adding several people who had asked about task management and see if they have come up ways of using Hepta for task management. The most direct example I see the manual calendar whiteboard from <@!915157914447118347> [2]

author: Bigspud

content:
**How we prioritize features**

Value — Will this feature significantly help our users think and learn better?

Workflow Impact — Can this feature improve the entire workflow of how our users will use Heptabase?

User Impact  — How many users need this feature?

Frequency — How frequently will our users use the feature if we build it?

Urgency — How painful will our users feel if we don’t have this feature?
author: Alan Chan

content: I would like the feature that there is a tag filter in whiteboard page, so that we can focus on some tags like "unanswered" cards on the whiteboard, and the other cards will be blurred.
author: alphonse.yc

content: Got it. Really appreciate the feedback and thank you for rooting for Heptabase! You've given tons of great feedback :)) Let me create a short write-up about how we prioritize goals.
author: Alan Chan

content: Obviously it's not my call to make feature prioritization. I was hoping to hear more direct answer though. All features have values for some users if not all users, and that's where prioritization comes in. Delete all would matter for some but surely less so for others. My read is that Heptabase is not interested in switching existing users from existing note-taking tools Roam, Obsidian, logseq, and that probably explains why we still see large gaps in Wikilinks, tags, and table stakes like delete notes. On the other hand, whiteboard features and performance get more love, probably to create differentiation and not get too much behind similar whiteboards Kosmik and Scrintal. I'm rooting for Heptabase with my money and notes, and would hope Heptabase be more opinionated and declare clear prioritization goals.

author: Carl-bot

content: Want to bump this up as offline images is a deal breaker and I don't see that on the roadmap. It's disingenuous for Heptabase to get user content from local to somewhere without explicit consent, even after users turn off sync Heptabase still copy images from local to outside. If Heptabase does not prioritize e2e encryption it seems better to support a pure offline mode first that can read / write notes and images locally

author: 苏无因

content: I wonder if we can keep track, or version, the spatial relationship around card through its lifetime. In the note or text centric word, we build and add to individual notes, and version control system like git can help track the evolution of a note (and can travel back in time when needed). Hepta offers another dimension for the card, the spatial relationship around a card (what kind of cards are "around" a card, was a card directly created on a whiteboard or in the timeline, what links a card point) can change over time but as a user I have no easy way to recall and trace these spatial relationship changes. The questions I want to ask about a card includes "why did I create this card in the first place?" "why did I move this card here and from where?" and I imagine a version history on what cards are around a card would provide clues to these questions.

content:
功能需求：这种一次打开多个卡片的界面也能够云同步，最好还能保留出一个索引，随时打开卡片集合。
需求原因：这种多卡片打开模式下，是对于某些知识点很舒适的编辑布局，所以希望能永远云记录下来有哪些卡片，形成一个索引（这个索引最好还能标记一下）。另一方面，在两个电脑来回编辑时，有时候这些有关系的卡片的内容还没编辑完，一旦更换电脑这些结构就不存在了，不方便换电脑后继续在原来的基础上进行编辑。

content:
<#856016076311101470> 

I love the ability to collapse bullet points by clicking on the bullet. 🙌

However, I'd also love the ability to click "into" the bullet point to focus on that set of bullet points (similar to how Logseq and Roam Research do it).

In order to facilitate this, you could add a simple "toggle" icon when there are already a series of bullet points. If there is only one bullet point, then clicking on it would take you "into" that bullet point so you could add more. 

Again, just like how Logseq and Roam do it. 

Finally, it would be awesome if we could also `Opt-Click` on a bullet point to open that set of bullet points in the sidebar, to work on editing them further there.
author: crsmoore

content:
<#856016076311101470> 

I'd love to see slash commands for time/date, etc. 

Like... 

`/now` - outputs the time in 12-hr AM/PM format (or 24-hr format, as an option in the Settings)
`/today` - today's date
`/tomorrow` - tomorrow's date 
`/yesterday` - yesterday's date 

These would all be output according to how you have your Time/Date set in the settings.

And these would also dynamically link to the entries/cards created on those dates (as an option). It would link to a filtered view for all the entries/cards created on that date (as one idea).

author: Vincer

content:
**+Bonus: Extruse bullet point/block as card (on boards)**
Similar to how some apps allow for block reference/link or embeds, but as cards on the boards.

The idea could be very simple to use (for the users, front end): simply dragging a block from a card into the board... and then a new card would appear on the board of just that block *with some color, shape and other denotations that its a diferent type of card*

Extruded/Transcluded blocks (ideas)
- dont exist as files/notes on library, just as cards on boards. Dropping any number of blocks into a board would add 0 new notes on the library
- they render/sync with the note they were extruded from. Editing the content on such a block-card would change that block in the main note and vice-versa
- red/dotted/special line: when clicking/focusing on a extruded block it would show a a special/different line from it to the its source note (If said note is on the board) 
-- only show on focus
-- clicking on the line jumps/moves the board to the main note as focus
-- *chooses the closest source note on board, if any is on board:* in case the user have multiple instances of the parent note to a block-card, said line would be drawn to the closes one only
-- *i tought a noticeable thiner and bright line would work best* thiner subtly informing its a sort of link that is not permanent like user draw lines
author: Vincer

content:
**Feture Request: Zoom in-out(focus) on bullet lists**
I know it may feel like a stretch but ever since ive stumbled into the first outliner that could fold/unfold bullets and also zoom in/focus on any bullet on any depth i never left then- to the point that, to this day, i juggle around multiple apps with some outliner on the side just because of that.
For the first time ever i feel like an app have been so close to be my one go-to app(Hepta💖), very very few things in the way- and now that hepta implemented foldable bullets it became even closer...

If hepta ever allows for zooming on bullet points i, and assume many others would be able to ditch outliners in a heartbeat. Even more so considering what the team has show on future plans and other features, hepta could easily seduce workflowy, dynalist and logseq users

But could go even further on it i think:

content:
关于连线，有一个明显的问题：如图所示，如果下方卡片所在位置不是上方卡片的正下方，连线会从侧边出来，看起来很丑。

由于这个问题的存在，我只能极力避免上下摆放卡片，尽量采用左右放置卡片的布局。显然，这改变了我的使用习惯，限制了 Heptabase 的自由度。

如果允许把侧边的连线拖放到底部，可以解决问题。

author: Alan Chan

content:
** use case to justify my feature request of "Auto-fit"**

Here's my actual use case **to explain why I expect the feature "Auto-fit" will save me time**. It is not project management, I took these notes when I read something, which could be books, papers, or web articles.

There are 21 cards involved, grouped into 11 blocks, labeled as 1, 2, ..., 11 in the diagram. In each block, I may have several cards glued together vertically. The cards in purple mean that they are not finished, or need further clarifications or corrections. 

I had four independent reading activities at different moments. On Monday, I read something and created (1,2); On Tuesday, I wrote (3,4,5,6,7),  Wednesday (8), and Thursday (9,10,11).

Take the example of how I arranged the cards in (3,4,5,6,7). I created two cards for two parallel ideas so I put them together vertically, so I got block 3. There are some ideas to explain cards in block 3, so I created cards 4,5,6 and attached them to cards in (3) horizontally. Furthermore, I created block (7) which includes two cards, to explain card 5. (Before attaching block 7, I adjust the width of card 5.) 

That's how I created all these cards. Now I found that the card in (7) answers a question raised in a card in block 2, so I connect them. Totally, I have four connections, all of which are for question-answer relations.

In this use case, I spent <10% time moving the cards or creating connections. I create a card and attach it to other cards vertically or horizontally. I spent the most time adjusting the height of the cards and keeping cards glued together. Then I expect **a feature of "Auto-fit"** will do the most job for me.

content:
**Info Shortcuts**
Just improvements for usability with keyboard
***1 Escape Key to close card info***
Just recently i started  running hepta in a small window with a note on fullscreen or the timeline as a sort of 'pop-up notepad' for alt-tabing and taking notes on references (say a browser for example).
Now that we have tags on the infopanel (love it!) i used then in such a small window and i couldnt close the info panel- reason being it only closes on clicking outside, and there was no outside in such a small window (but i loved how the infopanel looked 'fullscreen' in a tiny window)
I intuively went for the escape key to close but no-go
***2 Open Card Info***
a hotkey to open the info panel while were typing (without the need to lift the hand from the keyboard)
(example: alt+i)
***3 Tag Shortcut***
like something as simple as typing T when a infopanel is open, 'cliking'/starting a new tag
1- with info open, pressing T or + to start adding a tag
2- ***general tag shortcut***
A shortcut that opens the infopanel already on add-tag from cards selected (whiteboard, library) and during writing.

content:
I'm just going to create this message and edit it if I think of any other stuff

- Allow dragging and dropping of files either into an existing open note, or into empty space to create a new note with the doc

- Not sure if docs are stored as DB globs, but a local storage mode to allow self-service VC and sync like Obsidian would be nice

- Change `New Whiteboard` action on the map page to only be invoked on double click, like the new card behaviour on board page.

- Do not preserve cards that are empty, such as from a double click

- Whiteboard and Map zoom to fit (and maybe miro style minimap)

- "Immersive" editor shamelessly stolen from Obsidian that shows full unrendered MD on the currently active line

- Temporarily note editing modals (maybe on single click). This would be really useful in the map view to be able to click note titles to see and edit their content without entering into the whole board.

- This is a very ambitious one, but allow boards within boards and then make the Map a board itself as an immutable "root board"

- Support for mermaid diagrams

- keyboard shortcuts please please please please

- allow sharing of web clippings via OS service or browser extension

content:
In most cases, I repeat the following actions: put relevant cards together vertically; I update these cards or insert new cards in the middle. Finally, I need to adjust the height of the cards to fit the content. The cards look as in the figure below.

Can we select these cards, and right-click "auto fit" to: (1) automatically adjust the height of each card to fit the content; (2) align vertically according to the left border of all selected cards; (3) keep the bottom of each card attached to the top of the next card?

If cards are not too lengthy, this feature saves a lot of time/energy in formatting.

A similar feature request is in https://discord.com/channels/812292969183969301/856016076311101470/942484292762742864

content:
I use duplicate cards on the same board quite often.
Trying to keep my number of boards at a sane level im growingly doing more then one flowchart on a board- for example subject X, one flowchart/maping of the subject is on the left of the board while another way to layout/map the same subject is on the right...
...and both dealing with many of the same cards

Some other uses
-alternatives/proposals: like a side by side columm or row of how to order something, with alternatives side by side
Say if it were book chapters each 'alternative' would draw the same chapter/content cards but each in a different order
-folded vs unfolded
Im getting used to listing a bunch of cards in folded state in one are of the board, while in another area the same cards are unfolded with relational arrows draw
-Media
A reference image being next to what it would be useful, that same reference as a card avoids pasting the same image on a bunch of cards.
I also like the idea of using images as a sort of landmark to browse a larger map- the same card with a big warning image would be easy to spot in the 3 areas it was put, next to something theyre warning about

I also often do duplicates temporarily- few of my boards are 'static', most are more like sketches. Even when i want to map something in 1 singular way i may do more then one arrangement before deciding wich is best and then deleting the copies

content:
Imagine you: 
1. Go to `Timeline`
2. Then go to `Tags`
3. Then go to `Map`
4. open `whiteboard A`
5. open card `X` in split screen
6. open card `Y` in split screen
7. open card `Y` in full screen

If you click backward multiple times, I guess I would expect to go back step 7 to 1 passing trough all steps. 

I see it's not as simple as in chrome, because in chrome it's just pages, and you're simply moving back and forward. In Hepta you're like in different contexts (Timeline, Map, Whiteboard, Card in Split Screen, Card in Full Screen), and going backwards I would expect to jump between all these contexts. 

Other example: 
1. You're in `Whiteboard A`
2. open card `Y` in split screen
3. open card `Y` in full screen

If I click `back`, first I would expect to switch from full screen to split screen, if I click `back` again, then I wold expect that the split screen disapears and you can only see `Whiteboard A`

This is how notion does it as well (video below)

content: (UPDATE: I searched "nested" in the forum and see that we will have to wait a little bit to see whether nested whiteboards will be implemented in some fashion. I am soooooo hoping that it is.) Just started using Heptabase today. REALLY liking it. It appears that <@!368602215474266113> 's post above is probably related to my question, which it sounds like has been asked often: **will Heptabase eventually give us the option of creating maps within maps (or boards within boards—or nested boards)?** I didn't see anything about this on the roadmap—hence my question. The annotated screenshot below shows what I'm hoping I will eventually be able to do in Heptabase.
author: Forrest

content:
I know the idea of nested boards has been brought up numerous times, and I _think_ I have an idea that might allow for something similar based on my recent whiteboards, with two possible implementations.

**Motivation/Pain point:** Boards involving complex topics are becoming more common, and some could use some strong interlinking. However, a full reference to the card could be distracting from the active board's content and, while related, may not be _relevant_ to that particular discussion; that is, having the linked card on another board may detract from the content, as I'm starting to feel. The boards I've been working on are all highly related, yet contain discrete topics that don't overlap much; having a way to navigate through my boards _without_ creating copies of the relevant cards would be **incredibly** helpful.

**Solution #1: "Ghost" Cards**
Effectively, these cards act as simple pointers to a card on another board; it would display nothing but the card title and target whiteboard, possibly using the card's color for both outline and text, with the board's default background color for its background (or transparent) to quickly identify it. Double-clicking on it would then jump to the whiteboard and navigate to the card as though the user has first navigated to the whiteboard and then clicked on a link to the card.

**Solution #2: Card Link Change**
Another option would be to allow existing card links to navigate to other boards; I imagine it being part of a context menu for the links that allows you to jump to existing instances on other boards. The result of following this mode of navigation would be identical to Solution #1.

author: an

content: When tags are hierarchy supported, people start using it to "organize" notes, and treated them as a new type of "smart folder." However, the purpose of tags in Heptabase is to help users quickly group the fleeting notes they capture, merge & rename these tags constantly until it reaches a state that make sense, and eventually throw cards that have certain tags into a whiteboard to think and organize them visually. So the final organization should be based on whiteboards, not based on hierarchical tags.

content:
Great product, I'm impressed at how polished the whiteboard feels.

Would it be possible to more quickly "extract" chunks of content into a new card?

Use case:

- I'm writing a card, it's getting large
- I realize that one part is starting to go off on a tangent, and probably deserves to be it's own card

What I currently do:

- Double click to create a new card
- Cut the contents of the part I want to "extract" into the new card
- Go back to the original card and "@-link" the card I just created

What would be nice:

- Highlight the content I want to turn into a new card
- Hit some keyboard shortcut, command, or something in a menu
- The content is replaced by a link to a newly created page

I'm imagining something like Notion's *"Turn into Page"*, or *"Extract variable/method"* in an IDE

content:
**Tags v2 additions**
Im so happy tags are back! Just a few ideas on what i felt missing:
**Adding tags on Board  & Library Views**
Probably already planned. I find tags most useful when they can be applied as soon as cards are created or while theyre being edited, and that happens a lot in board view and in the library view too. 
**Show Boards a note is in (in tag tab)**
Just like the popup saying 'this card is in x baords' that appear in board view, i think showing the same when a card is selected in tag-view would be great.
That way we could go to tags for overview and filtering and then choosing one to see in what contexts its in. Like in boardview the 'this card is in x boards' allowing to jump straight to a board with the card in focus
**Expanded View(in tags tab)**
An option to open a note in large full-screen view from the tags view
**Renaming Tags**
An option to rename tags. I thing that would work best from the tags-tab/view- as each tag is selected it shows the tag as a title on top of the list on the current build.
A button could be there next to the tag/tittle in tag-view to rename

-Tab bar(show/hide): a single button/icon with a number(1 by default, 1 tab) next to hepta logo, cloud icon or on the main view, for showing/hiding the tab bar

content:
**Right Click Draw Single Line (without changing tool)**
I miss being able to from a card draw a single line like in the early versions, back when hepta was meta
I like the tools, the draw line tool is useful... but i often want to make a single line from 1 card to another quickly then shift gears as a whole.

The idea:
Right click and draging on any card starts a line draw to conect cards- but its just that 1 line
as soon as a connection is made or the drag droped (whitout finishing a connection) the line draw mode stops

content:
For context:
I frequently remenber to jot down something that doesnt pertain to a board im currently writing/working on.
And i feel the need to write it down asap or at least create an entry, to continue later.

Also the reason for another idea/request:
author: Vincer

content:
**Board Lists on sidebar**
Similar to how the library can unfold in a list per-board, having the map entry also be unfoldables as a list on the sidebar, listing all boards.

Since hepta doesnt allow for multiple windows everytime im using it im suffering from a lack of ways to quicky jump & switch between boards.
Having a list on the sidebar for a 1 click board switching would be great, as clicking on map then visually scaning where a board is +clicking takes too long.

**Bonus: shortcut search**
On top of that i love apps that offer a quick search function; on pressing the shortcut a popup shows, for quickly typing, with a list being featured in realtime.
I think said pop-up could have 3 modes/filters (notes, tags, boards), being 1 popup for the 3.
| ##############################|
| _______(search input)
|**[notes]**  *[boards] [tags]* (buttons, shifting filters)
|-  list of recent entries
|- (updated to best match of whats written)
| ############################|

Then
-1 shortcut for each (notes, tags, boards)
the shortcut opens the above popup with one of the filter modes selected
-pressing something like tab switches to the next filtering mode

For reference obsidian and eagle(eagle.cool) have quick search like this.
Eagle use this exact pattern, the popup shows up and pressing tab switch whats searched (folders, documents, tags, etc)

content:
Desired feature  for Hepta:

These features are more towards ‘project management’ approach of using Hepta.

1. Grouping cards in white boards

2. User-define relationship between card

3. More attributes of card - e.g. date/time, reminder, status selection…

4. When a card has time attribute, then there can be a calendar view of the cards

content: Another idea: A label on the arrow could be itself a card or at least it could include a reference to a card / #tag or [[ ]]. This would make labels much more powerful.

I don't like tones of colors for cards, so I would be happy to change them. You can look at RemNote, ObsidianMD or Roam how they allowed for custom CSS :).

author: Cato Minor

content:
这是两种不同的思路，用超链接和frame，前者是为了提高 whiteboard的可复用性，并且使知识和信息的结构更容易“重构”。超链接本身也从数据底层更好体现上层信息的逻辑层级结构，frame 的话还是停留在展现层
---
These are two different ideas, using hyperlinks and frames, the former to improve the reusability of the whiteboard and to make the structure of knowledge and information easier to "refactor". The hyperlinks themselves are also a better representation of the logical hierarchy of information at the top level from the bottom of the data, while the frames are still at the presentation level.

content:
1. 选中文本块后可快速拆分为新的卡片
2. 每个块前面增加一个把柄，方便调整顺序
3. 预览：鼠标悬浮到链接时的预览、插入链接时的预览（mention）
4. todo 样式列表
5. Timeline中的卡片：右上角应该增加 info 图标，点击后能看到卡片信息
6. multiple spaces
7. 从Card Library中打开卡片后，卡片左上角也应该出现最大化的按钮
8. 多种 highlight 颜色
9. Whiteboard界面提供全局搜索功能（事实上，全局搜索应该是在任何界面都能唤出的）
10. 将 Web Bookmark 作为特殊 block，能显示目标网页标题和简短摘要
11. 增加表格支持
12. 增加ARM版本（for apple silicon)
13. Markdown 快捷键（主要是针对 Heading）
14. Roadmap（让用户对于后续功能改进和上线有一个时间预期，以更好决定在什么时间开始能把 Hepta 作为主力平台）
15. (对第 6 点进一步扩展）spaces/folders/whiteboards 即增加 folders 对 whiteboards 进行归类
16. Time travelling for whiteboard —— 通过动态的方式来展示 Whiteboard随着时间如何发生变化，帮助人们理解事实、知识等的变迁
---
1. Text blocks can be quickly split into new cards when selected
2. a handle is added in front of each block for easy reordering
3. preview: preview when mouse hovers over link, preview when link is inserted (mention)
4. todo style list
5. cards in timeline: an info icon should be added to the top right corner to show the card information when clicked
6. multiple spaces
7. when opening a card from the Card Library, a maximise button should also appear in the top left corner of the card
8. multiple highlight colours
9. a global search function in the Whiteboard interface (in fact, the global search should be available in any interface)
10. Web Bookmark as a special block that displays the title and a short summary of the target page
11. add support for tables
12. add ARM version (for apple silicon)
13. Markdown shortcuts (mainly for Headings)
14. Roadmap (to give users a timeline for subsequent improvements and launches to better determine when they can start using Hepta as their primary platform)
15. (To expand on point 6) spaces/folders/whiteboards i.e. adding folders to categorize whiteboards
16. time travelling for whiteboard - a dynamic way of showing how the Whiteboard has changed over time to help people understand how facts, knowledge etc. have changed

content:
I want to share my current framework on MIRO board and some ideas that rhyme with hepta. First thing when I saw hepta, I told myself that this is what I really need. Canvas to work with the text, toy with ideas, link them and arrange as I develop my ideas, and work with manuscript. 

Before hepta in my constant rotation I had obsidian to work with text and thoughts (and I still use it occasionally), but first work with ideas had been done one MIRO board. I toy with ideas with materials that I might need, and because MIRO is extremely good in visualizing, using mindmaps, sticky notes, blocks, text and drawing tools. It have been doing work splendidly. In hepta I thought information could be organized into something similar. You can look at my current MIRO board, where I arrange things for lectures, there I usually put videos, pictures, sometimes docs (pdf), later after lecture is delivered content from MIRO is systematized in OBSIDIAN (now in hepta).

So my question is, can embeded video from youtube be added on whiteboard? Pictures? Audio files? Whole PDF docs?

You can look at how I am organizing everything on the MIRO here, it's open for comments. https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_lrwNk9E=/?invite_link_id=105653858980

author: Sams_Here

content:
FR: Projects/Spaces
Between personal knowledge, planing, amateur writing, breaking down a project or planing and even planing a tabletop rpg session... the many uses/areas/subjects i want and im starting using hepta for dont really overlap.
Separating boards and clustering borders apart on the map works, but i also wanted to do quick notes directly on the timeline and use the timeline +NoWhiteboard on the library as a way to mark and find what were quick-and-dirty notes vs the notes organized in boards... by wich point they all become mushed together, i mean, the different unrelated areas a note pertains to.

Also i often write notes that have similar titles and first lines, even tough theyre from highly different areas- and that makes searching messy when im working on one thing, i rather not have results pertaining to what i dont need right now showing up in search

Tags +filtering options (in search, library, etc) could cover that- but in the abscence of tags...

The idea:
Similar to Notion's workspaces, Onenotes notebooks or Obsidian's vaults- a way to separate areas, be it inside the same library or 'entirely'
They could be called spaces, areas or- Given the name Heptabase... bases? just an idea
Anyway switching bases could be/feel like switching libraries entirely.
It would probably make sense if they were actually different libraries, but from a users perspective it would only matter how they`re set in the frontend (and backing up options, like exporting a json with all bases/areas or individually, both options).

Btw exporting bases/areas individually would be great for cooperative work, a company sharing wikis or even the community sharing stuff (like it happens over at obsidian, the most famous one being the Lyt Kit). Thats also how Eagle works too wich i found very useful for sharing and space management- and while hepta probably wont be a disk space hog for most users, as it expands and local images are added and over time...

PS: just for clarification, the need for a inbox is just so users could see recently added cards while a board wasnt opened, as well as an way for then to position then on a board.
Otherwise cards 'sent' onto a board from the outside would have to be added 'randomly' somewhere- and if implemented like that it would be confusing
author: Vincer

content:
Feature Request: Add to Board context menu (right click)
Re-arranging some boards and deciding to use cards into others, i had to remenber wich cards interested me from one board to ad to the other, then using the sidebar scroll or remenber the titles of each, or just go reading until i found the right ones...

I just realized it would be much more practical in such cases to right click on a card and choose a "add to another whiteboard"
Upon clicking the list of boards would show up, and clicking on any would add the card there

+Inbox/Incoming
Whenever a card is added/sent to an whiteboard without it opened, a bottom bar called inbox or incoming would show up on the whiteboard.
It could be like the sidebar import only horizontal, or vertical but on the left (to make it distinct)

Ps: i can see many cases where cards could/would be added on a whiteboard without it opened
considering current practical uses and future ones:
-drag and droping from the library straight into a whiteboard on the sidebar
-from one whiteboard already opened(as described above)
-from a co-worker/extra seats/users (future, if/when theres colaboration)
-from a share-to/grab on mobile or even chrome/browser extensions in the desktop
etc etc.
What i mean is it would be good to start thinking and experimenting how to do such a thing sooner then later as it would be handy in the future anyway
