author: Bou

content:
Thinking about it earlier, I believe it'd be nice to be able to rebind keys based on context, as `esc` functions differently according to the overall state. I think having a Settings page for hotkeys, as <@!779015270311395370> suggested, would be a great addition to the app—especially with context included in this—and create more space for power-users to thrive as more features are added~

Right now, I think it's still pretty easy to immediately bind new features to new hotkeys as relevant, though I also have a feeling that we're going to be reaching a tipping point for easy and unique hotkeys for important features sooner rather than later. I think it might be better to prepare for that sooner rather than later. This isn't to say that it needs to be an immediate concern—the number of features with hotkeys is still fairly small—but that it should be given _some_ priority to make sure it beats out the _need_ for it.

author: JohnAtl

content: One thing I'll point out regarding structure: While Obsidian (and I believe Logseq) supports nested folder structures, presently Meta's notes are stored in a flat folder. While this limits structural hierarchy, it also means there's less time focusing on _where does this note belong_—leaving more time to focus on the content (and, if desired, tags for discoverability).
author: Curio Heart

content:
A _big_ tip that gets brought up regularly in the Obsidian server is actually a deceptively simple question: __What is your goal with this?__

For me, it comes in a few parts:
- I love to learn new things, so I need a space to explore new concepts and connect them with what I already know.
- I do a considerable amount of creative work, and need to be able to work on associated materials without being distracted by everything else.
- Because I also have a habit of digging deep into personal issues, I also need a place to focus on those thoughts.

Knowing what your goals are with why you're wanting to manage your knowledge will help you figure out what you need to do to organize it, and what kind of structure would be most helpful based on the apps you're using.

content:
FR: So let's say someone is using Meta heavily for scheduling and actions that are _date-driven_. Typically, these kinds of cards _expire because the event is now in the past_. It would be nice to set an expiration date for a card, so on that date the card pops up and promps the user to delete or extend the expiration date.  **This might also be approached as a** _reminder card_.
This would solve the following problem: accumulating out-of-date cards and not having to search and clean them out manually and/or a way to be _reminded to do something with that card_.

author: Hovo

content: I’m glad this is being brought up again,  the future of knowledge management and work software depends on two major pillars: connectedness and flexibility/moldability. I think by now it’s clear that connectedness is a major thing in Meta’s technical roadmap, I think moldability should be put on the same level of importance. Being able to create levels of whiteboards adds a whole new dimension to meta, allowing users to better mold the tool for their purposes. As a user, I can already tell how helpful it is for me to connect my thoughts and ideas at a card level. Imagine if we could do this at whiteboard levelS (capital S because this could be infinite) think of it as gaining the ability to zoom out and look at our idea “galaxies” and how they relate to the universe of ideas and then being able to zoom in to the atomic level. We could build a whole “universe”

author: Alan Chan

content:
__FR__
**Better Help(shortcuts+)**
Ive experienced a bug or just some misunderstanding of metas shortcuts (as i explained in a bug report)
Regardless of the bug(or even being a bug) thing is i couldnt double-check if it was some mistyped shortcut since i couldnt check what were all the shortcuts.

My first instinct was clicking on the question mark/help button- but that only replays the tutorial

My sugestion: *Turning the help button into a more general overview of shortcuts and behaviours* - including the replay tutorial as one of the options on it.

The best way(i think) would be the help to open a sidebar similar to the split view, showing a document of sorts (preferably with a gray background, so its not mistaken by how cards look- ui colored), with links and or folded bullet-points, listing every useful topic on behaviour, use and shortcuts- from double clicking a card in split view to expanded view (just released feature) to everything else- anything that can be done with mouse, clicks and typing that isnt obvious on the interface should be there

This same help document could/should have a 'replay tutorial' button on the top, just moving the current replay feature to inside the help.

I know filling documentation like that eats time (even more so on such a fast paced build push, love agile iteration) but i imagine having a overview of all commands and interactions like that is needed anyway during development, probably in a table- so the help could be written in such a way that its basically the same table devs refer to for already stabilished commands/interactions.

author: Vincer

content:
__FR__
**SPACES(libraries)**👈🙏
Problem: meta automatically saves data via browser without handling things like a "library" file.
That works fine, but for people wanting to use meta for different uses- different subjects, life vs work, whatever- they have to put everything in the same meta library
-mentioning cards way more then wanted may appear that would never matter for a boards particular subject
-scrolling through the card library or graph gets increasingly noiser as cards and boards grow- if they do so on multiple areas with no overlap they get in the way
**solution: spaces/libraries**
Like Notion and Miro have spaces or Obsidian have library files...
A space/library working just like it is, but creating new ones and switching showing different card libraries and boards, without one appearing on the others
-from a code and backedn perspective it could still be the same single library- instead spaces would work as top level folder/filters that "pretend" each exists alone
author: Vincer

content:
__FR:__
**Paste Images Directly**
I love using images for reference, and in some cases images overlaping one another (more useful to have then slighty overlaping taking less space)
As it is i paste images into cards just fine, but resizing (new feature, loving it) is wonky (theyre resized separatedly from the card theyre in), and in cases where i only want the image theres always the card border around
**Request:**
Pasting an image (image on the clipboard) when in a board, without any card in focus, pasting the image as its own card container
-on Card Library the image would count as 1 card
-title: filename(if possible), but even automatic names or ids are fine (ex: img1, img2)
-resizing the image like cards
author: Vincer

content:
__FR:__
**Sticky Card Scrolling**
*my memory may fail me, but i think meta used to behave like this request*
Whenever content is bigger then a cards size on the board a scroll bar appears that allows scrolling through it all(wich is great)
**problem/usecase**
Clicking outside of a card springs the cards content back to the top.
-i often want to read one thing while im writing another, i can do that in meta but if the reference is a long text i have to rearrange the board/resize a card so i can operate on another card and still see the content i want
-i have inserted cards into other boards because of one part of said card thats relevant; In longer cards i end up loosing context as to why ive put that card in that place (i wish i could scroll to the relevant part and leave it there)
The alternative would be creating cards with excerpts of other cards... but that would mean more work and multiplying cards with redundant content (already in other cards)
**simple solution:**
having meta remenber scrolled cards position (the scroll showing even with the card out of focus, to show visually its scrolled down)
**better solution**
Remenber scroll position like above, but also showing the cards title(first line) as a bar on the top as soon as a scrolled card leaves focus
author: Vincer

author: Vincer

content:
__FR:__**Follow Through Links:**
Being able to click in a link/mention and go to where the card is in a board its in.
**problem:** 99 in 100 times i click a link im more interested in following a link to see the target in context (a board) then to insert its card on the board im in.
**solution (having it both ways):**
on click:
-if the card is in a single board, go to that board with that card in focus
-if its in multiple, showing the pop-up "this card appears in x boards" that already pops up in such cases
Alt Click:
using a key(ctrl, alt, shift, any modifier) +click **inserts** the card on the board were in (the current behaviour)

author: The_Badjer

content:
Hi @everyone ! Thanks for all the feature requests! Our community is getting bigger quickly, and we've received many feature requests both in this channel and during the onboarding sessions. Since we're a small team and have a limited time, we want to make sure we're spending time on the most valuable things.

Therefore, from now on, **we'll prioritize feature requests that contain a description of the problem**, which is "why I want this feature," **"how is the feature going to help with my use case and workflow,"** "how much pain do I have without this feature and why," etc. 

There will be a much **higher chance** we prioritize your feature request with more contexts you've provided. Thanks for understanding 🙂 Let’s build the product together!

Also, your feature request **will be prioritized if you're already taking notes in Meta** and have some use cases shared in <#856158746093944852> channel. If you're not using Meta at the moment, we suggested you get started first to see if you really need the feature 😄

content: Add a means to check the backup being imported.
author: Alan Chan

content:
Feature Request: **Add a means to check the backup being imported.** I was thinking about this a little bit ago while mentioning Meta in the Obsidian server, and I think having a way to validate that the file being "uploaded" to Meta is a valid `All_Data_*.json` file instead of something random could help prevent issues like what <@!710847265581039616> had a while ago when uploading a markdown file. I feel like even having a boolean flag (eg, `isMetaBackup: true`) in the JSON should help alleviate the issue considerably.

This could also make it possible to safely import individual files: If it doesn't have the flag, then it could _add_ the file to the data instead of overwriting.

author: EthanW

content:
Feature Request:
MAP VIEW IS AMAZING. Its one of the things i wanted most!

But one of the main reasons i wanted it was for making that sort of view/nesting per board.
A map view for tags globally is awesome, but big and complex boards could become extremely easier to navigate, visualize the big picture vs smaller things and overall more powerfull if they could do something similar.

I think nesting cards onto another (on a per board basis, not globally) would be the best solution- appearing just like map view.
Nesting like that btw would also achieve the kanban, another planed feature.

Also, coupled with board shortcuts to other boards, users would be able to nest and navigate fully via the board through the relationships amongst multiple boards pertaining to one another (for my usecase, pertaining the same project)
+it would in essence turn meta closer to a notion alternative for anyone who likes to make their own navigation, even better for that as a powerful dashboard+map since all cards are transcluded

content: I've been thinking about the feature I request, and what is feasible is that if you can let the user customize the type of cards I want to use. author: Thu Dang

content: Hi <@!779015270311395370> , thanks for the response. I think I will elaborate. So my problem is that sometimes I just want to write the tile of something, without having content in it. However, if I fold the card, I have to unfold it to draw the lines. My user journey to creating a title card right now: Create a new card -> make it smaller so that it is only 1-line long (takes like 1-2 secs because the arrow to make the card smaller is quite hard to find) -> write the title -> drag the arrow. If I use the folding option, then my user journey is: create a new card -> fold it -> make other cards -> then realize I need to draw arrow -> unfold title card -> draw the arrow(s) -> refold it. The unfold - refold takes some time if I constantly add more content cards and need to draw arrows. I am the type of person who has to see the arrow immediately, not the one who writes all the content cards and draws the arrows.

author: 𝑺𝒄𝒉𝒎𝒆𝒆𝒛𝒆

content:
Sometimes even dark-mode contrast is difficult for me to focus on properly, and I need something less intense to be able to work, like right now.[1] It'd also be nice to have a lower-contrast mode, or a way to set some colors—like the whiteboard and cards.

[1]: This is a very real problem for me sometimes. It's easiest for me to work digitally, but it's difficult when even dark mode gets hard to focus on. I had to turn on Win10's Night Light just to focus on discord to type this, and have been working from Journal just to avoid needing to do more work than necessary moving the writing to my vault. Also because the off-white paper look with orange-ish lines is very easy for my eyes to focus on, and the app's pencil makes it a naturally very low-contrast way to write on my computer. It literally meant the difference between writing roughly 150 words and not getting a damn thing done.
author: Curio Heart

author: Alan Chan

content:
🔥 **Linking Options**
*i know internal links are in the works and will come with metaeditor*
But i would LOVE to see better linking options, for external links
1) *rename*
pasting a link prompting and or allowing to rename its alias

2) *uri* links 👈
(i think thats what theyre called)- the links that tell the os to open a file/path with a given application...
Ever since i discovered then ive been using then whenever i can, like linking to onenote pages in obsidian and vice-versa
For us using multiple apps its the only way to bridge (to an extent) the gap between tools
im hyped for metaeditor (only thing missing for me to heavily take notes in meta) but it will handle the hyperlinking magic within meta
I just need that bridge, that portal, so i can more easily jump through things... id rather be ideating and linking in meta, writing longform and outlining in obisidian
now that i just embeded meta inside obsidian... *this just became my most imediate wish*

3) Meta Links!!
The other way around- i was surprised when i found out notes didnt had a url link on the adress bar
it makes sense the way the app works, but then we'd need some way to generate links- to open/go-to Meta and open a specific note (also whiteboards)
*i understand at this point it would only work when opened on a browser with cached metanotes in it*

content:
**Type Tool**
A button somewhere on the board with a letter symbol (T for example)
-Clicking on it changes the cursor to show a letter
-Clicking on a empty space would create a semi-transparent/dashed rectangle for tiping inside
-clicking away, selecting something else etc would hide the texts border
For typing outside cards as auxiliary text on whiteboards.
Additional text have no need to be listed globally, non taggable etc- just existing per whiteboard
-Clicking on it showing the outside rectangle again, for resizing its area (affecting line and word breaks, like it works on cards)
+shift resizing would increase/decrease the rectangle and its contents as a whole
author: Vincer

content:
1) multi-select (ctr/cmd or shift clicking)
+selection box (click dragging on empty space drawing a selection box)

2) duplication via drag
notes can already be imported in multiple instances
with some hotkey (ctrl, shift, etc) pressed down, selecting then dragging a note creating a duplicate instead
(the user would then be dragging the newly made copy)
+keep the imported notes(via import) as unstyled (default style assigned to the card globally, if in the future that becomes a thing)
+but drag-duplication should copy the duplicated card as it is on the board (size and colors) - minus the arrows of course
author: Vincer
